Dinner

In

Dr. William Holland Wilmer world
famous eye specialist and former director of the Wilmer Institute of
Ophthalmology, was honored last
Monday night at a banquet given in
the Welch Library. The occasion for
the testimonial was the retirement
of Dr. Wilmer from the staff of the
Johns Hopkins Hospital.
Amid the impressive surroundings
of the medical library, tribute was
paid the renowned savant by many
of his friends, associates, and former
patients; an assemblage including
many celebrities.
Willard, Harlan Express Regrets
Personal regrets at the retirement
of Dr. Wilmer were expressed by
Daniel Willard, president of the
board of trustees of the university,
and Henry D. Harlan, president of
the board of trustees of the hospital.
Highly laudatory remarks were
made by Dr. Joseph S. Ames, who
described the eye specialist's attributes as "great kindness, great
sympathy, infinite and perfect courtesy and true gentlemanliness."
Mr. Herbert Satterlee, a board
member of the Wilmer Foundation,
presented Dr. Wilmer with a volume
containing comments of eye specialists from all over the world on the
achievements of the retiring director.
Institute Founded In 1922
The institute which Dr. Wilmer
has brought to such fame was founded in 1922 as a means of making his
skill available for the treatment of
the greatest possible number of sufferers and for the instruction of physicians. Noted ophthalmologists have
come there for conferences; young
physicians for study; and notables
from all over the world for treatment.
Dr. Dean C. Woods will succeed
Dr. Wilmer who intends to resume
his practice in Washington.

Nice Solicits Aid
Of Dr. Hollander
Invites Educator To Serve
On Board Preparing OldAge Pension Legislation

Dr. Jacob H. Hollander, Abram G.
Hutzler, Professor of Political Economy at the Johns Hopkins University,
was recently appointed by Governor-elect Harry W. Nice as a member
of a committee of ten persons to prepare legislation for old-age pension
in Maryland.
Dr. Hollander, a native of Baltimore, has had considerable experience in domestic and international
affairs. He served as chairman of the
Baltimore municipal lighting commission. In 1900 Dr. Hollander was
appointed by the Secretary of War
as a commissioner to revise laws relating to taxation in Porto Rico; and
while engaged in this service, he was
appointed by President McKinley as
treasurer of Porto Rico. He organized the treasury department and devised the present revenue system of
the island ("Hollander Law"),, resigning after seeing it in successful
operation.
In addition Dr. Hollander has also
served as associate editor of the Baltimore News. From 1931-32 he was
chairman of the Tax Survey Commiterian Murphy, Edward Donnelly, To tee of Maryland. At present he is a

By JEVVETT GOLDSMITH
Though it is generally supposed
that the Hopkins Y. M. C. A., which
is celebrating its anniversary this
week, is 50 years old, no definite
verification of this fact can be found.
A history of the Y. M. C. A., written in 1889 by Marion B. Learned,
the president at that time, says:
". .. Gradually the need of an organization made itself manifest and
on November 25, 1884, a meeting was
held at which a preliminary organization was made, and it was decided
to have a Y. M. C. A." If this information is corect, the organization is
fifty years old. The 1890 edition of
the Medley, predecessor of the Hullabaloo, however, states:
"In 1882, a Young Men's Christian
Association was organized at the
University." This would make the
organization fifty-two years old.
However, whether it be the fiftieth or the fifty-second, some anniversary is being celebrated. The anniversary week was officially ushered
in last Tuesday at noon by a faculty
reception and luncheon. That evening, Dr. Lynn Harold Hough, dean
of the Drew Theological Seminary,
addressed the University Supper
Club on the subject, "Realistic Thinking and the Sanctions of Religion"
as part of the half-century celebration. Later in the evening, he delivered a University Lecture on Religion on the subject "Critical Days for
Civilization."
On Wednesday, Dr. Hough addressed a graduate student luncheon
on "Research and Interpretation,"
and the first of a series of three undergraduate forums and a series of
three freshman forums were held. Yesterday morning, the alumni
held its half-century reunion and
dinner. Dr. Hough once again spoke,
this time before a student assembly.
The holding of forums was continued.
Today's program calls for a lunch[Continued on Page 4, Column 1.]

Archaeological Society

Dr. David M. Robinson, head of the
Hopkins department of art and
archaeology, will address the Washington Archaeological Society next
Monday, in the Chinese Room of the
Hotel Mayflower, in Washington.
The next lecture which Dr. Robinson wil deliver at the University,
will be held Thursday, December 13,
5 p. m., in Latrobe Hall. This address
will be public. Dr. Robinson will show
the slides of his expedition to Olynthus and also some taken from an
airplane
At present, Dr. Robinson is exhibiting some special French paintings at the Baltimore Museum of Art.

Band Accompanies Juniors
The Johns Hopkins Band accompanied the juniors to Homewood
Field, where they marched around
singing. Freshmen, sophomores, and
seniors were dragged from the
stands and forced to join the marchers. The entire group went to the St.
Johns stands where they recaptured
Benny Arnstein, kidnapped freshman.
The juniors were prepared to guard
the goal posts but enough policemen
were on the field.
Meetings at which future projects
will be discussed are being held every
week by the class officers. When the
plans are formed, they will be presentd to th entire class at a future
assembly.

OfPraf. Gamow 7 uesday
"Nuclear Physics" will be the subject of a series of lectures to be delivered by Profssor G. Gamow, of the
George Washington University, under the sponsorship of the Johns
Hopkins University department of
physics.
Professor Gamow was formerly at
Leningrad before coming to the
George Washington University. The
first lecture will be given next Tuesday, at 3 p. m., in Rowland Hall 105,
and will be continued on each Tuesday thereafter for 20 weeks.
The course is open to anyone upon
payment of a special fee of $5 to the
department of physics.

Honoring the late Edward Lucas
White, author and Latin instructor
of note, the Tudor and Stuart Club
will hold a memorial meeting December 3 in Levering Hall, at which
the Hon. John S. Dickinson, assistant
secretary of commerce, will be the
principal speaker.
In addition to the talk by Mr.
Dickinson, who wa§ editor of the
News-Letter in 1911-12 and who delivered the 1934 Commemoration Day
address here, brief addresses are to
be made by Miss Lizette Woodworth
Reese, prominent Baltimore poetess,
and Hon. Louis H. Dielman, executive secretary of the Peabody Institute.
At the memorial meeting, which
will begin at 3 p. m., Kipling's "Recesional," a favorite of the late Mr.
White's will be sung, together with
other songs, by C. Reese Dietrich,
baritone.
Edward Lucas White was an honorary member of the Johns Hopkins
Tudor and Stuart Club.

Although it hasn't been generally
circulated, the managers of the legitimate theaters here in Baltimore
are more or less up a tree. The only
show to play here thus far has been
Walter Hampan's repertoire, which
was in performance last week. Ford's
house had a booking for the premiere
of Gather Ye Rosebuds with Walter
Connelly as its star, but that show is
to open in Philadelphia instead. The
O'Flynn, another premier, was scheduled to open shortly at the Auditorium, but the break-up in that was
due to the fact that the stage was
not large enough to accommodate the
sets.

Dinner

In

Dr. William Holland Wilmer world
famous eye specialist and former director of the Wilmer Institute of
Ophthalmology, was honored last
Monday night at a banquet given in
the Welch Library. The occasion for
the testimonial was the retirement
of Dr. Wilmer from the staff of the
Johns Hopkins Hospital.
Amid the impressive surroundings
of the medical library, tribute was
paid the renowned savant by many
of his friends, associates, and former
patients; an assemblage including
many celebrities.
Willard, Harlan Express Regrets
Personal regrets at the retirement
of Dr. Wilmer were expressed by
Daniel Willard, president of the
board of trustees of the university,
and Henry D. Harlan, president of
the board of trustees of the hospital.
Highly laudatory remarks were
made by Dr. Joseph S. Ames, who
described the eye specialist's attributes as "great kindness, great
sympathy, infinite and perfect courtesy and true gentlemanliness."
Mr. Herbert Satterlee, a board
member of the Wilmer Foundation,
presented Dr. Wilmer with a volume
containing comments of eye specialists from all over the world on the
achievements of the retiring director.
Institute Founded In 1922
The institute which Dr. Wilmer
has brought to such fame was founded in 1922 as a means of making his
skill available for the treatment of
the greatest possible number of sufferers and for the instruction of physicians. Noted ophthalmologists have
come there for conferences; young
physicians for study; and notables
from all over the world for treatment.
Dr. Dean C. Woods will succeed
Dr. Wilmer who intends to resume
his practice in Washington.

Nice Solicits Aid
Of Dr. Hollander
Invites Educator To Serve
On Board Preparing OldAge Pension Legislation

Dr. Jacob H. Hollander, Abram G.
Hutzler, Professor of Political Economy at the Johns Hopkins University,
was recently appointed by Governor-elect Harry W. Nice as a member
of a committee of ten persons to prepare legislation for old-age pension
in Maryland.
Dr. Hollander, a native of Baltimore, has had considerable experience in domestic and international
affairs. He served as chairman of the
Baltimore municipal lighting commission. In 1900 Dr. Hollander was
appointed by the Secretary of War
as a commissioner to revise laws relating to taxation in Porto Rico; and
while engaged in this service, he was
appointed by President McKinley as
treasurer of Porto Rico. He organized the treasury department and devised the present revenue system of
the island ("Hollander Law"),, resigning after seeing it in successful
operation.
In addition Dr. Hollander has also
served as associate editor of the Baltimore News. From 1931-32 he was

By JEVVETT GOLDSMITH
Though it is generally supposed
that the Hopkins Y. M. C. A., which
is celebrating its anniversary this
week, is 50 years old, no definite
verification of this fact can be found.
A history of the Y. M. C. A., written in 1889 by Marion B. Learned,
the president at that time, says:
". .. Gradually the need of an organization made itself manifest and
on November 25, 1884, a meeting was
held at which a preliminary organization was made, and it was decided
to have a Y. M. C. A." If this information is corect, the organization is
fifty years old. The 1890 edition of
the Medley, predecessor of the Hullabaloo, however, states:
"In 1882, a Young Men's Christian
Association was organized at the
University." This would make the
organization fifty-two years old.
However, whether it be the fiftieth or the fifty-second, some anniversary is being celebrated. The anniversary week was officially ushered
in last Tuesday at noon by a faculty
reception and luncheon. That evening, Dr. Lynn Harold Hough, dean
of the Drew Theological Seminary,
addressed the University Supper
Club on the subject, "Realistic Thinking and the Sanctions of Religion"
as part of the half-century celebration. Later in the evening, he delivered a University Lecture on Religion on the subject "Critical Days for
Civilization."
On Wednesday, Dr. Hough addressed a graduate student luncheon
on "Research and Interpretation,"
and the first of a series of three undergraduate forums and a series of
three freshman forums were held. Yesterday morning, the alumni
held its half-century reunion and
dinner. Dr. Hough once again spoke,
this time before a student assembly.
The holding of forums was continued.

Field, where they marched around
singing. Freshmen, sophomores, and

Honoring the late Edward Lucas
White, author and Latin instructor
of note, the Tudor and Stuart Club
will hold a memorial meeting December 3 in Levering Hall, at which
the Hon. John S. Dickinson, assistant
secretary of commerce, will be the
principal speaker.

Dickinson, who wa§ editor of the
News-Letter in 1911-12 and who delivered the 1934 Commemoration Day

be made by Miss Lizette Woodworth
Reese, prominent Baltimore poetess,
and Hon. Louis H. Dielman, executive secretary of the Peabody Institute.

will begin at 3 p. m., Kipling's "Recesional," a favorite of the late Mr.
White's will be sung, together with
other songs, by C. Reese Dietrich,
baritone.

id armament competition and decline to discuss interational agreement or organization? If so, on what

roduce the old result?
"3. For a nation to be secure under the competitive
rinciple it must be stronger than any possible rival.
Vhat becomes of the rival? Is he to go without dense? How shall defense of each be managed under
us plan since the security of the one means the inacurity of the other? Does William Randolph Hearst

iggest that rival will accept the situation and not resort

ave this arm entirely' in the hands of prospective
vals?"

who gathered for last year's tussle

taken around the Naval Academy by
his captors. On Friday, the prisoner
helped pile wood for the bonfire and
in the afternoon Admiral Sellers
called to see him.
